revision.text: [[File:Map of Tibet- "TIBET CONFIDENTIAL" "Ethnographic Boundary of Tibet" "Approximate Line of Communist Advance" and "Reportedly occupied by Communists" "11518, CIA, 2-50" February 1950 map- 305945 11518 01.jpg|thumb|Map including '''Yarkand''' (CIA, 1950)]] [[File:Txu-oclc-6654394-nj-43-5th-ed.jpg|thumb|Map including SO-CH'E ('''YARKAND''') ({{w|U.S. Army Topographic Command|USATC}}, 1971)]] ==English== ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{alternative form of|en|Yarkant}} #* {{quote-book |en |url=https://archive.org/details/petralogytreatis01pinkrich/ |year=1800 |title=Petralogy |volume=I |author={{w|John Pinkerton}} |publisher=White, Cochrane, and Co. |page=280 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/petralogytreatis01pinkrich/page/280/}} #*:Goez, who travelled to Tibet in 1602, in describing '''Yarkand''', the capital of the kingdom of Kasgar, in Little Bucharia, mentions, that a commodity, particularly acceptable in China, was a kind of marble or jasper, found in Kasgar*. #* {{quote-book |en |isbn=978-0-691-13589-2 |url=https://archive.org/details/EmpieresOfTheSilkRoad/ |year=2009 |title=Empires of the Silk Road: A History of Central Eurasia from the Bronze Age to the Present |author={{w|Christopher I. Beckwith}} |publisher={{w|Princeton University Press}} |page=240 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/EmpieresOfTheSilkRoad/page/n267/}} #*:The Manchu-Chinese replaced the Junghar imperial coinage of East Turkistan with Manchu-Chinese coins they began minting at '''Yarkand''' in 1759. ====Translations==== {{trans-see|Yarkant}}
